Graphical abstract Enhanced bimetallic Rh (0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0 wt%)-Ni 10 wt%) promoted with La2O3(15 wt%) and CeO2(10 wt%)/alumina supported catalysts for ethanol steam reforming compared to their monometallic counterparts is reported. The larger stability of bimetallic Rh-Ni supported catalysts can be due to a: i) cooperative effect of Rh and Ni activities; ii) larger capacity to gasify the methyl group produced from the decomposition of the intermediaries, iii) non-accumulation of acetate species and, iv) favoring the WGS reaction. The 1%Rh-10%Ni bimetallic catalyst shows the best catalytic performance towards H2 selectivity, operating stability over 144 h of reaction and almost non-carbon formation after 24 h on steam. A significant decrease in the carbon-deposition of the 1%Rh-10 wt%Ni bimetallic catalyst, displaying a 70- and 560-times larger stability than their respective monometallic 1%Rh and 10%Ni counterparts was detected. The study of deactivation/regeneration process of the 1%Rh-10%Ni catalytic system indicates that a reactivation treatment fully recovered the catalytic activity of the deactivated catalyst at least in two regeneration cycles. In both cycles, the bimetallic 1%Rh-10%Ni catalyst was stable until 72 h of reaction appearing as a promising catalyst for the reaction of reforming ethanol at mild temperature conditions. Keywords Bimetallic catalysts Ni-based catalysts Ethanol steam reforming Hydrogen production Catalyst regeneration Carbon deposition 1 Introduction Hydrogen is a promising energy source, however, paradoxically, the main hydrogen production method remains gas natural reforming, which is a fossil fuel. In this context, steam reforming of bioethanol arises as a promising path to H2-production since bioethanol can be obtained from the fermentation of different biomass resources, such as sugar, starch, cellulose, agro-industrial wastes, forestry residues, and even potentially from the organic fraction of municipal solid waste. In fact, some studies have reported that coupling between bioethanol production by fermentation and bioethanol reforming could be economically viable [1,2]. The ethanol steam reforming (ESR), is an endothermic reaction, in which the ethanol reacts with water steam producing carbon dioxide and hydrogen like is shown in Eq. (1): (1) C H 3 C H 2 O H + 3 H 2 O → 6 H 2 + 2 C O 2 Δ H 298 ° = + 173.7 k J m o l - 1 The mechanism of ESR involves first, the ethanol dissociative adsorption, then ethanol undergoes dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde and acetyl species, and subsequently it is decompose to CO and methane, or it is oxidized to acetate by the addition of support-bound hydroxyl groups. Further reactions such as water gas shift (WGS) and steam reforming of methane (SRM) promote H2 production from carbon monoxide and methane, respectively, with the latter being previously generated in the ESR reaction. On the other hand, reactions as ethanol dehydration to ethylene (C2H4), dehydrogenation of methane (CHx) and ethylene (C2Hx) and the so-called Boudouard reaction can lead to carbon deposits formation. Reaction pathways depend on the physicochemical properties of catalyst and reaction conditions, which are widely studied in order to avoid rapid catalyst deactivation. The chemical nature of metal and support strongly affect the reaction routes and catalyst stability so that different promoters have been used in this sense to search decrease the catalyst deactivation. In addition, metal-support interactions rather than the individual components themselves contribute to greater catalyst stability; which could favor dispersion of the active metal in the form of small nanoparticles or to facilitate degassing of the carbon deposits formed during the reaction, as we have already been reported [3–5]. Both noble and non-noble metals have shown be suitable active species for ESR [6–12]. Among these, Ni has been widely studied owing to (i) its high CC and OH bond-breaking activity [13], (ii) relatively low cost and (iii) its well-known catalytic behavior in the WGS reaction [4,14]. In the case of noble metals, the Rh have presented the higher resistance to coke formation whereby it is one of the most studied active phases for this reaction [8,15–18]. Recently, bimetallic catalysts have acquired increasing interest, since these catalysts often exhibit stability and enhanced activity, which is attributed to a synergism between both metals. In this context, bimetallic catalysts based on non-noble metals (Ni-Co) were prepared by Zhao et al. [19] using a perovskite-type oxide (LaNi1−xCoxO3) as the precursor to be evaluated in ESR reactions. Ni-Co alloy nanoparticles were highly dispersed on ZrO2. Bimetallic catalysts exhibited very good catalytic performance for ESR, including high selectivity to hydrogen production and a remarkable stability, which was attributed to the synergistic effect caused by both cobalt and nickel. In another study, carbide species which act as an intermediate in the filamentous carbon growth were totally inhibited by the presence of trace amounts of Rh on Co/CeO2 catalysts, whereas on monometallic catalyst, the accumulation of strongly bonded carbide species was observed [20]. Mondal et al. [21] reported a lower reducibility of NiO promoted by addition of Rh for bimetallic catalysts compared with monometallic ones. Hydrogen selectivity enhanced from 59% to 73% for Rh-Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 in comparison with Ni catalysts. The improvement in the activity of bimetallic Ni-Co catalysts compared to monometallic ones was explained by Moretti et al. [22] in terms of a synergetic effect between cobalt and nickel species which enhances the reducibility of both metal oxide phases. On the other hand, bimetallic catalysts of Ni-Co/LaFeO3-La2O3 prepared by Wang et al. [23] presented an excellent anti-sintering and high catalytic activity for ESR. Nevertheless, carbon non-deposition ability for bimetal catalysts was similar to those of single metal catalysts. Palma et al. [24] recently showed a decrease in the rate of carbon formation when a support of SiO2 for a Pt-Ni/CeO2 bimetallic catalyst was used. Despite, Pt-Ni/CeO2 catalyst without SiO2 obtained the highest perfomance for H2 and stability compared to monometallic ones [25,26], the support assured a better dispersion of active species, which resulted in a more stable catalytic system which show that the role of the support should not be neglected. Since there is currently not a stable catalyst for the reaction studied, the aim of this paper is to evaluate as affect the addition of Rh (0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0 wt%) the stability of a supported catalyst of 10 wt%Ni/15 wt%La2O3-10 wt%CeO2-Al2O3 which was previously reported by us for ESR reaction [4,5]. Ni metallic catalysts were modified with a noble metal (Rh) in order to achieve a synergistic effect between both metals, searching enhance the catalysts stability. With this objective, the physical chemical characteristics of catalysts, selectivity to H2, reaction pathways and catalysts stability to long reaction times of steam reforming of ethanol at a mild temperature (773 K) was evaluated. A comparison with Rh and Ni monometallic catalysts was carried out. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The supports were synthesized by impregnation of γ-Al2O3 (Glider SBET = 189 m2 g−1) with an appropriate amount of cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.9% Merck) and lanthanum nitrate (La(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.9% Merck) to obtain solids containing 10 wt% CeO2 and 15 wt% La2O3. After impregnation, solids were calcined at 923 K for 6 h under static air. The Ni catalyst was prepared by impregnation with aqueous solutions of nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 99.9% Merck) using a similar protocol, to obtain 10 wt% Ni catalyst and annealing under air atmosphere at 773 K with a flux of 30 mL min−1 during 4 h. Different amounts of Rh (0.25, 0.50, 0.75, 1.0 wt%) were subsequently impregnated over the Ni catalyst and then calcined at 573 K. For the monometallic Ni/alumina supported catalyst, previous work indicated that the large stability was achieved with 15% La2O3 and 10% CeO2 [4]. The samples were labeled as xRhNi/La-Ce-A, where La = 15 wt%La2O3, Ce = 10 wt%CeO2, A = Al2O3, Ni = 10 wt% and x = 0.25, 0.5, 0.75 or 1.0 Rh wt%. The solids were reduced before characterization or catalytic evaluation under a H2 flow of 30 mL min−1 at 773 K during 1.5 h. Monometallic catalysts of Rh and Ni had 1 wt% and 10 wt% respectively and these are denoted as Rh/La-Ce-A and Ni/La-Ce-A. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were carried out using a Bruker diffractometer Model D4 Endeavor and nickel filtered CuK α radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm) under constant instrument parameters (40 mV, 20 mA, angles between 5° and 90° and step size of 0.02°). A semiautomatic Micromeritics TPD/TPR 2900 apparatus equipped with a TCD was used for temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiments. Deconvolution of TPR spectra was performed by using Origin 9.0 software. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were carried out with a VG Escalab 200R electron spectrometer equipped with a Mg Kα X-ray source (hν = 1253.6 eV) such as we reported in [4]. TEM micrographs were used to determinate particle size (> 1 nm) using a Jeol Model JEM-1200 EXII System. The catalysts post-reaction were evaluated by thermogravimetry (TGA/SDTA851 Mettler Toledo). Coke deposited after 24 h of time on stream (TOS) was determined measuring the mass loss in the used catalysts during oxidation under flow of 20 vol.% O2 in N2 (temperature programmed oxidation, TPO). TPO was performed from 303 K (5 K min−1) until a final temperature of 1273 K. The coke amount was expressed as mgcoke gcat −1 or mgcoke gcat −1 h−1. The atomic ratio of both metals after reaction was measured by XPS analysis. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation in steam reforming of ethanol and regeneration test 100 mg of catalyst diluted with 200 mg of SiC (both in the 0.18–0.36 mm particle size range) were placed in a 1.7 cm ID stainless steel tubular reactor with a coaxially centered thermocouple for catalytic activity tests. A water:ethanol ratio of 3:1 was used in all cases and feed to reactor by an HPLC pump with a total flow of 137 mL min−1 (dilution ratio: mol Ar/(mol H2O + mol C2H5OH) = 0.76 and GHSV = 26,000 h−1). Catalyst stability was measured at 773 K during 24 h of TOS. The reaction products were followed using a quadrupole mass spectrometer (HidenModel HPR-20) as previously reported [4]. Finally, the reactivation process was carried out by a heat treatment at 723 K for 1 h under an air stream (100 mL min−1) to burn-off carbon deposits. 2.4 Evaluation of adsorbed species on the catalyst surface by in situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) In situ DRIFTS of adsorbed species after a flow of ethanol:water (1:3, 30 mL min-1) passing onto catalysts were performed with a JASCO FTIR6300 spectrometer equipped with a liquid-nitrogen-cooled MCT detector and a KBr beam splitter. The sample is placed in a DRIFT chamber (Spectra Tech) with a ZnSe windows. The first spectrum was recorded at room temperature and then the temperature was increased stepwise up to 723 K and spectra were recorded every 50 K after equilibration for 2 min on stream. More details of experiments were previously reported [3]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization In Fig. 1 the X-ray diffractograms of monometallic and bimetallic reduced catalysts shows diffraction peaks corresponding to γ–Al2O3, CeO2 and Ni° phases. The broad diffraction peaks at 2θ = 37.2°, 45.8° and 66.7°, correspond to γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS 86–1410), while those peaks at 2θ of 28.60, 33.1, 47.6 and 56.5° were respectively indexed as (1 1 1), (2 0 0), (2 2 0) and (3 1 1) planes of the fluorite structure (JCPDS 081-0792) of CeO2, indicative of segregation of the Ce-phase over the Al2O3 surface. No species due to lanthanum were observed by XRD indicating a large dispersion. Regarding metals, three major peaks attributed to Ni° (1 1 1) at 44.5°, Ni° (2 0 0) at 51.8° and Ni° (2 2 0) at 76.5° appeared, while lower amount of Rh (below the detection limit) did not allow its identification All Ni catalysts promoted with Rh showed similar XRD patterns to catalyst monometallic of Ni and no diffraction lines could be attribute for Rh species (JCPDS 05-0685), as also was reported by Lucrédio et al. [27] for catalysts prepared in the same conditions. In the other hand, in the bimetallic RhNi catalysts it can be seen an increasing in the peak width of Ni°, attributed to an increase in crystal size of nickel compared to the Ni/La-Ce-A monometallic catalyst. In Table 1 is shown the Ni particle sizes estimated by TEM by measuring more than 100 nickel clusters. Bimetallic RhNi/La-Ce-A catalysts exhibited a larger particle size than the monometallic Ni/La-Ce-A with no effect in the Ni particle size by Rh content (Table 1 and Fig. 2 ). The observed trend suggests a close interaction between metallic Rh and Ni clusters. The low Rh content (˜ 1 wt%) does not allow to measure the metal particle size in the TEM micrographs. It can be seen in Fig. 3 reduction profiles of bimetallic catalysts quite different to those observed in the monometallic counterparts. The Ni monometallic catalyst shows a broad reduction peak from 600 to 900 K, attributed to the reduction of both NiO species with different interaction degree with the support and a surface reduction of CeO2, whereas the peak at higher temperature (> 900 K) is due to the bulk reduction of the ceria [28]. In the bimetallic catalysts the shift of the reduction peaks at larger temperature, indicating a large interaction between Ni and the support, in line with the reported hardly reducible NiAlxOy and NiAl2O4 species [29–31]. The increase in Rh content favored the reduction of some species of Ni2+ as a raising in H2 consumption about 690 K was observed that could be attributed to the H2-spillover effect occurring on noble metals which promoted the reduction of other reducible species. The TPR characterization (Fig. 3) indicates that the reduction peak attributed to ionic Rh species (˜ 443 K) clearly shifted towards lower temperature in bimetallic catalysts, this peak corresponds about 3.3% of the total consumption, while in the monometallic Rh catalyst, corresponds to 13%. This observation could indicate a strong interaction of rhodium species with the support and/or the other metal; as it was reported by Kugai et al. [14], Rh enhances reducibility of NiO, while the reducibility of RhOx species in Ni-Rh/CeO2 catalysts decreased. These findings confirm the existence of a Ni-Rh interaction, in line with XRD results. XPS measurements were performed on bimetallic and monometallic reduced catalysts (Table 1). La3d5/2 BE was observed between 834.7 and 835.0 eV, substantially larger values than those reported for La2O3 (833.2 eV) and LaAlO3 (833.8 eV) standards. Therefore, these values have been attributed to deficiently coordinated La3+ ions [28], confirming highly dispersed La2O3 in the 15 wt% of La2O3 catalysts. For Ce3d5/2 level, a BE of 883.0 eV, characteristic of CeO2, was determined. Fig. 4 shows the Rh 3d spectrum. Reduced catalysts exhibited a doublet centered at 307.0 and 311.7 eV, which could be attributed to binding energies corresponding to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 levels of Rh°, respectively [32,33]. The XPS spectrum of Ni 2p (not shown) shows a peak at around 853 eV which was deconvoluted into two components, one at 851.6 eV and the other at 855 eV attributed to Ni metallic and Ni2+ species, respectively. It is also detected that Ni is found principally as Ni2+ in the bimetallic catalysts with a dependence on Rh content (Table 1). The lowest content of Ni2+ species detected on Ni-monometallic catalyst is in line with Kugai et al. [32] on bimetallic Ni-Rh supported on CeO2 catalysts. The authors report that Ni monometallic catalyst did not exhibit the presence of Ni2+ species, whereas bimetallic Ni-Rh catalysts containing 1 wt% Rh shows a shoulder around 855 eV attributed to the presence of Ni2+ species, indicative that the synergic interaction of Ni–Rh favoring the partial oxidation of metallic Ni to Ni2+. In our catalysts the addition of Rh increased both metallic Ni mean particle sizes and the Ni2+ content, as can be seen in Table 1. In line with TPR results, bimetallic catalysts have a large amount of Ni-species strongly interacting with the support and the other metal; therefore, the reduction process at 923 K does not lead to a complete reduction of Ni-species. When increasing the Rh amounts, Ni2+ binding energy shifts 0.5 eV confirming a potential interaction between both metals. The calculated Rh and Ni atomic ratios by XPS are shown in Table 1. It can be seen in Table 1 that the surface Rh extent in the bimetallic with 0.75 and 1.0 wt% catalysts do not change significantly respect to the monometallic. Regarding to surface Ni, even though the degree of exposure nickel decreases in the bimetallic catalysts, their large metallic dispersion give always a larger atomic surface ratio with regard to the nominal. The lower amount of Ni exposed in the bimetallic catalysts can be related to an increase in Ni particle size, as it was shown by the TEM. 3.2 Catalytic evaluation and catalyst stability in the steam reforming of ethanol Catalysts were evaluated during reaction in terms of ethanol conversion, product distribution and stability. Complete conversion was achieved for all bimetallic catalysts with H2, CO2, CO, and CH4 as the main reaction products (Fig. 5 ). At 673 K, catalysts exhibited a similar product distribution, showing the H2>>CH4>CO2>>CO following order. It should be point out that the catalyst containing 1.0% Rh was the only one exhibiting a slightly larger selectivity towards CO2 rather than CH4. On the other hand, for RhNi catalysts, the presence of Rh, led to an easier hydrogenation of CH3 species generated during the breaking of CC bond compared with Ni monometallic, since this latter exhibited a lowest CH4-selectivity [4,5]. This low selectivity could be attributed to the accumulation of CH3 species on the active sites, which would lead to the loss of activity and catalyst deactivation. Furthermore, due to only the monometallic Ni/La-Ce-A catalyst exhibits an important ethane production at 673 K, it can be clearly seen the effect of Rh addition. It is detected in bimetallic catalysts that even small amount of Rh induce an increases in the dehydrogenation reaction to acetaldehyde than in ethanol dehydration, supported by the presence of acetaldehyde in bimetallic catalysts not detected in Ni monometallic catalyst counterpart. In Fig. 5 it can be also observed that in bimetallic catalysts increasing reaction temperature decreases the CH4 selectivity, probably due to methane reforming, since selectivity towards H2 and CO increased. This reaction reversed the selectivity from CO2 and CO, as can be seen in Fig. 5. Moreover, the presence of both metals changes substantially the products distribution of reaction compared to monometallics ones, in a larger extent at lower temperature (673 K). In the bimetallic catalysts the break of CC bond is favored decreasing the formation of acetaldehyde compared with the monometallic Rh-catalyst. For the other hand, in the Ni monometallic catalyst, acetaldehyde was not detected and the detected acetone disappear after Rh addition. Additionally, the sharp is decerease of CO selectivity in bimetallic catalysts is another feature that suggests synergy of the metals. To evaluate the effect of Rh content on the stability of the catalysts, an experiment with 24 h of reaction at 773 K was carried out. Conversion and product distribution are presented in Table 2 . In catalysts containing Rh at 0.25 and 0.50 wt%, the production of ethane and acetaldehyde with time on stream (TOS) evidenced a catalyst deactivation, since these products do not appear at the beginning of the reaction. Ethane is an undesired by-product (dehydration) and the presence of acetaldehyde indicates that the subsequent reactions of oxidation and CC bond breaking did not take place in either catalyst. Moreover, on the 0.25 and 0.50% Rh catalysts an increase in CO2 production at 24 h was observed indicating that the Boudouard reaction is being favored over time. This observation is consequence of the dropping in the H2-production due to a catalyst deactivation. This fact, together with the possibility of dehydrogenation of methyl species, as evidenced by a sharp decrease in methane at 24 h of reaction, could be the reaction routes responsible for the large carbon deposition observed on 0.25RhNi (Table 2), in agreement with the previous reported by Lucrédio et al. [34] for Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/MgAl, containing Rh at 1.0 and 1.5 wt% catalysts. The observed catalytic performance of the bimetallic Rh(0.25 wt%)Ni(10 wt%)/15 wt%La2O3-10 wt%CeO2–Al2O3 catalyst indicates the promotion with Rh increases the carbon deposition rates compared to the non-promoted catalysts attributed to segregation of Ni-species on alumina during the reaction; on the other hand, CH4 decomposition would be favored on Rh as in the Rh-NiMgAl catalyst reported [34]. Product distribution at 2 and 24 h of reaction shown in Table 2 indicates almost no differences between monometallic and bimetallic catalysts in terms of conversion and selectivity. Eventhough, catalyst stability was strongly enhanced when Rh was present at 0.75 and 1.0 wt%. For the 0.75 and 1.0 wt% of Rh catalysts, a carbon deposition rate of 2.2 and 70 times lower than the Rh/La-Ce-A monometallic catalyst is detected. Compared with the Ni/La-Ce-A monometallic catalyst, the decreasing was still more pronounced, the carbon deposition rate was 18 and 560 times lower than monometallic for both 0.75RhNi/La-Ce-A and 1.0RhNi/La-Ce-A, respectively. Despite catalyst containing 0.75% of Rh did not exhibit a large loss of catalytic activity it also showed an important amount of carbon deposits. This ambiguous behavior could be related to the formation of filamentous carbon, as seen by TPO-DTG analysis (Fig. 6 ). When filamentous carbon grows outward of catalyst surface this can pull the metallic particles outside without loss of catalytic activity [35] as metallic site remains free of carbon deposits. TPO-DTG measurements (Fig. 6) on bimetallic catalysts after 24 h of reaction revealed that Rh addition lead to a carbon deposition with different reactivity since all catalysts except the one containing 1.0 wt% Rh exhibit more than two peaks between 673 and 1173 K. It was previously reported [29,36] that mass loss at 823 K is associated with adsorbed amorphous carbon on Ni or the support while mass loss corresponding to filamentous carbon with different graphitization degrees is observed at larger temperatures. In contrast, the 1.0% Rh bimetallic catalyst, shows a strong inhibition of filamentous carbon and very low amount of amorphous carbon since only one peak is observed at 823 K (Fig. 6d), while the other catalysts presented filamentous carbon. This result indicate that the proportion of Ni:Rh that gives rise to the most stable catalyst is 10:1 (wt%), since it had the lowest carbon deposition rate and that the TPO-DTG experiments indicates that its carbon is more reactive and easily eliminated in the reactivation process. The atomic ratio of both metals measured after 24 h of reaction by XPS (Table 3 ), indicates a lower exposure of both metals possibly due to sintering phenomena and/or covering of the metallic particle by carbonaceous species. After reaction, no changes for the surface ratios for the 1.0 wt%Rh contained catalyst were detected (see Table 3). This could be due to the very low deposition of carbon on this catalyst as was demonstrate by TPO-DTG results in Table 2. According to : (i) an almost null carbon deposition on the 1%Rh-10%Ni bimetallic catalyst supported on 15%La2O3-10%CeO2-Al2O3 (1.0RhNi/La-Ce-A) after 24 h of reaction, (ii) a larger carbon deposition rate on the 10%Ni (Ni/La-Ce-A) and 1%Rh (Rh/La-Ce-A) monometallic catalysts supported on 15%La2O3-10%CeO2-Al2O3, (iii) no presence of acetone with TOS in bimetallic catalysts and (iv) a larger CO2/CO ratio production on the 1.0RhNi/La-Ce-A bimetallic catalyst, it is possible to suggest a cooperative work among the metals favoring the WGS reaction and decreasing the rate of carbon deposition. It is likely the sequential impregnation of the metallic precursors favored the interaction between them and, consequently, gave rise to the desired synergy. In the sequential impregnation, the addition of the second metal will have a larger possibility of depositing itself very close to or in intimate contact with the first metal added. The close interaction between metals that favored the cooperative work has been also reported by Li et al. [37] who obtained larger performance of the Ni-Pt catalyst prepared by a sequential method, than when using the co-precipitation method. Authors attributed their observations to the Pt being located preferably on the surface of the metallic particles in the method of sequential impregnation. 3.3 Experiments of catalyst regeneration The catalyst containing 1.0 wt%Rh-Ni/La-Ce-A was chose to perform regeneration experiments carried out exposing it under ESR experiments for several hours until features associated with deactivation was observed. Then, a thermal treatment at 723 K under air flow was carried out to eliminate the carbonaceous deposits from the catalyst. Fig. 7 shows that the catalyst was stable after 144 h of ESR reaction, exhibiting only slight changes in C1 products and the formation of C2 and C3 products after 96 h. At 168 h of reaction, the catalyst showed activity loss since H2 selectivity was reduced. Two regeneration cycles were performed on the material achieving the complete recovery of its catalytic activity (Fig. 7). In both cycles, the catalyst showed signs of deactivation after 72 h; however, it was still able to break CC bonds since C2 species were not found. The latter suggests that regeneration processes do not strongly modify the active phase of the catalyst; therefore, a regeneration process is viable in this catalyst. 3.4 Evaluation of adsorbed species on the catalyst surface by DRIFT spectroscopy This analysis was achieved on the catalyst containing 1.0 wt%RhNi/La-Ce-A and its Rh/La-Ce-A and Ni/La-Ce-A monometallic counterparts (Fig. 8 ). After a flow of ethanol:water (1:3, 30 mL min−1), species adsorbed onto catalysts at different temperatures were investigated by in situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy. Upon the adsorption at 303 K, the ethoxide specie was identified in all catalysts by the IR bands corresponding to δas(CH3) (1450 cm−1), δs(CH3) (1390 cm−1), ν(CO or CC) (1163 cm−1), νas(CCO) monodentate (1100 cm−1), ν(CC) (1080 cm−1) and νas(CCO) bidentate (1060 cm−1). The acetaldehyde specie also was detected by its characteristic band between 1650 and 1709 cm−1 assigned to the ν(CO) stretching of adsorbed acetaldehyde species in its η1-configuration. The presence of acetaldehyde was confirmed by a strong band at 960 cm−1, assigned to the ρ(CH3) vibration in η2(C,O)-acetaldehyde. The appearance of bands corresponding to CO at this temperature (303 K) (1800–2030 cm−1), observed only for the Rh/La-Ce-A catalyst indicates activity for the CC breakage at low temperature in this catalyst. It can be also seen that the evolution of the surface species with the temperature depend on the catalyst. When temperature increases progressively, an asymmetric broad band in the region of 1400–1600 cm−1 grew on the catalysts, which is associated to the acetate species (1570 and 1450 cm−1) [38,39]. The peaks corresponding to those species are strongest for the Ni/La-Ce-A catalyst even at 723 K, while on the 1.0RhNi/La-Ce-A catalyst the signals corresponding to acetate species were always very small during analysis. These results indicate the possibility of different reaction pathways, above 473 K, bands attributable to COO species decreased considerably for the 1.0RhNi/La-Ce-A bimetallic catalyst, suggesting that the presence of Rh favors the breaking of CC bonds of adsorbed C2 species, while Ni/La-Ce-A monometallic catalyst showed growth and the stabilization of acetate bands by increasing temperature. Erdohelyi et al. [40] reported that highly stable acetate species hinder the migration of ethoxide species to the metal, and therefore its decomposition to produce H2 at the metal/support interface. In our case, the accumulation of acetate species on the catalyst surface can be responsible for the deactivation of the Ni/La-Ce-A catalyst during reaction, since it showed good results at the beginning of the reaction. The results of products distribution during the reforming reaction and adsorbed species studied by DRIFT along with our previous reported results [4,5,41] allow to propose a reaction pathway (Fig. 9 ). Ethanol may undergo dissociative adsorption on metallic sites while water adsorption could generate hydroxyl groups on the support. Ethoxide formed can undergo three different further reactions: (i) decompose to CHx, H2, and CO, (ii) dehydration to ethylene, which is the main responsible of carbon deposition, or (iii) dehydrogenation leading to acetaldehyde production. Under highly acid surfaces, the dehydration of ethanol could be the main route, leading to ethylene; polymerization of this could be responsible for carbon deposits. Because the acidity of the catalysts is controlled by the La2O3 and CeO2 promoters, the used 15 wt%La2O3 and 10 wt% CeO2 did not favor the dehydration pathway as shown in [4], the La2O3 and CeO2 can also help the degasification of carbon deposits. Therefore, the catalyst stability will depend on a dynamic equilibrium between the carbon deposition and degasification of carbon species. Additionally, acetaldehyde, which are not easily desorbed, can be transformed by dehydrogenation into acetyl; the latter can be further oxidized by surface oxygen coming from the support or by the −OH groups producing acetates. Once acetates are formed, CC bond breaking can occur, leading to C1 species such as CHx and COx by metallic particles, or they can accumulate, as observed for the Ni/La-Ce-A catalyst. Accumulation of acetates could lead to the formation of acetone. Recently, Almutairi et al. [42] evaluated the ketonisation of acetic acid on γ-Al2O3, TiO2, ZrO2 and CeO2 in the temperature range of 180–350 °C providing evidence to propose that one of routes of ketonisation was via a β-ketoacid intermediate, which involves participation of an enolate and surface acetate species as bidentate bridging acetate. Because in Fig. 8 signals of those species appears for the Rh/La-Ce-A, Ni/La-Ce-A and 1.0RhNi/La-Ce-A catalysts, it can be proposed that this route could be responsible of the acetone observed on Rh/La-Ce-A and Ni/La-Ce-A monometallic catalysts. Acetone can be also desorbed to the gas phase or undergoes subsequent reactions that lead to carbon deposition as was observed on the catalysts. On the other hand, CH4 formation will depend on the catalyst’s capacity to hydrogenate these species. Nevertheless, if this reaction does not take place, there would be a CHx accumulation blocking the catalyst active sites or leading to the formation of carbon deposits by CH4 decomposition [43,44]. The same occurs with CO, if it is not desorbed can lead to poison of the catalyst. As is shown in Fig. 8, on Rh/La-Ce-A catalyst appears the CO signal during all analysis, while on 1.0RhNi/LCA catalyst the signal progressively disappears, indicating that presence of Ni did not favor this adsorption. These observations indicate a cooperative effect between Rh and Ni metals being possible to affirm that the addition of 1% Rh to the catalyst of 10 wt%Ni supported on a 15 wt%La2O310 wt%CeO2-Al2O3 favored the decomposition of acetate species by CC bond break, the hydrogenation of CHx species and no accumulation of CO, which leads to a substantial decrease in carbon deposits of 560 times compared with the monometallic Ni catalyst. 4 Conclusions The effect of Rh content in bimetallic Rh (0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0 wt%)-Ni(10 wt%) promoted with La2O3(15 wt%) and CeO2(10 wt%)/alumina supported catalysts for ethanol steam reforming indicates that the bimetallic 1.0 wt%Rh-10 wt%Ni catalysts enhance the activity and stability compared to its monometallic 1.0%Rh or 10%Ni counterparts. The deposition of carbon in bimetallic 1.0RhNi/La-Ce-A catalyst decreased by 70 times with respect to the Rh/La-Ce-A and 560 times with respect to the Ni/La-Ce-A catalyst. The larger stability of the bimetallic 1.0RhNi/LCA catalyst can be related to i) a cooperative effect of Rh and Ni activities; ii) a larger capacity to gasify the methyl group produced from the decomposition of intermediaries, iii) no accumulation of acetate species and/or CO, and iv) favoring of the WGS reaction. Moreover, the 1.0RhNi catalyst supported on γ-Al2O3 modified with 15% La2O3 and 10% CeO2 showed excellent results in H2 selectivity, stability over the 144 h of reaction and almost no carbon formed after 24 h of reaction. Additionally, this could be regenerated at least 2 times, showing stability for 72 h of reaction in each of them. Therefore, the bimetallic 1.0%Rh10%Ni/15%La2O310%CeO2 alumina supported catalyst appears as a promising catalyst for the reaction of reforming ethanol at mild reaction conditions (T < 773 K). coredata.dc:description: Enhanced bimetallic Rh (0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0 wt%)-Ni 10 wt%) promoted with La2O3(15 wt%) and CeO2(10 wt%)/alumina supported catalysts for ethanol steam reforming compared to their monometallic counterparts is reported. The larger stability of bimetallic Rh-Ni supported catalysts can be due to a: i) cooperative effect of Rh and Ni activities; ii) larger capacity to gasify the methyl group produced from the decomposition of the intermediaries, iii) non-accumulation of acetate species and, iv) favoring the WGS reaction. The 1%Rh-10%Ni bimetallic catalyst shows the best catalytic performance towards H2 selectivity, operating stability over 144 h of reaction and almost non-carbon formation after 24 h on steam. A significant decrease in the carbon-deposition of the 1%Rh-10 wt%Ni bimetallic catalyst, displaying a 70- and 560-times larger stability than their respective monometallic 1%Rh and 10%Ni counterparts was detected. The study of deactivation/regeneration process of the 1%Rh-10%Ni catalytic system indicates that a reactivation treatment fully recovered the catalytic activity of the deactivated catalyst at least in two regeneration cycles. In both cycles, the bimetallic 1%Rh-10%Ni catalyst was stable until 72 h of reaction appearing as a promising catalyst for the reaction of reforming ethanol at mild temperature conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced bimetallic Rh-Ni supported catalysts on alumina doped with mixed lanthanum-cerium oxides for ethanol steam reforming
